newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada finally proposes start of Zairean mission.
newsitem.headline: Canada finally proposes start of Zairean mission.

text.p: Canada, impatient with indecision on the eastern Zaire refugee crisis, on Tuesday proposed that a military headquarters for relief operations be set up in Uganda.
Foreign Minister Lloyd Axworthy, announcing the proposal, also said Canada would push for air drops in Zaire to help those most affected.
But he made no mention of establishing corridors on the ground in Zaire to help more refugees return and to enable relief agencies deliver aid to refugees and displaced Zaireans.
"There is no clear-cut agreement on specific measures. Many are still claiming that they need more information," Axworthy told reporters with Defence Minister Doug Young at his side.

The U.N. Security Council mandated a Canadian-led military force for eastern Zaire on Nov. 15, but the subsequent return of about 600,000 refugees into Rwanda and confusion over how many remained has caused lengthy reassessment.
"Our view is that there needs to be some decisions soon on a course of action," added the minister, who together with Young has been forging the international response to the crisis in eastern Zaire.

"So we'll be proposing to our partners -- and we hope we can get some closure in the next 24 hours -- that we go ahead with the establishment of a military headquarters operation in Entebbe (Uganda) to help coordinate matters and prepare for future actions, including reconnaissance flights into Zaire," he said.
He said Canada would also "see if we can gain agreement to undertake a form of air drops into Zaire to assist refugees who have the most serious food needs."
The ministers did not criticise Rwanda, where most of the refugees are from, but that country's decision not to welcome a military force has made planning more difficult.
Military planners, led by Canadian Lt.-Gen. Maurice Baril, had been hoping to set up a headquarters in the Rwandan capital Kigali and to gain ground access to Zaire from neighbouring Rwanda.
Uganda also borders on Zaire, but does not have easy road links with the area the refugees are in.

The Rwandan government has argued that most refugees have returned, but a military planning meeting in Stuttgart during the weekend concluded that at least 250,000 refugees remained, in addition to Zaireans displaced within their own country.
Axworthy conceded he could not even guarantee agreement on these initial steps. "I think some of the countries are willing to work with us. Others still have questions."
Young said Canada and the United States both already had some troops in Entebbe. He did not give numbers, but several hundred soldiers are there now.
"There's no formal control-and-command operation in place yet because any of these decisions have to be agreed to by the steering committee that was part of the U.N. mandate," he said.
Axworthy said going forward with the headquarters and food drops were steps that could be taken in light of the continued questions on the part of some nations -- which he did not identify.
